#distancelearning week 3

We CANNOT try to recreate "normal" teaching conditions now in a time of distance learning nor should we make that a goal. 

We MUST consider what all students need and identify the best tools to deliver that.

#distancelearning week 3

Using a variety of tools that were built for cloud interaction/consumption like @Newsela, @listenwiselearn, @edpuzzle, @nearpod, and @Flipgrid are the PERFECT remedies for clunky text books that are boring, made for f2f learning, and inflexible.

#distancelearning week 3

Big points: 

A canned curriculum will not be flexible like I need in a time of distance learning. 

I need to hone in on the essential content and skills students need to be successful, well-rounded, and college, career, and life ready.

#distancelearning week 3

Students are likely not used to working w/video interactively. The first time you share @edpuzzle w/students use the "Go Live" mode. Students log in using Google, and will see an invited to watch the video live w/you. 

Perfect tool for remote teaching. https://t.co/C1zCcafsfP

#distancelearning week 3

Consuming video interactively is the superpower of @edpuzzle whose tag line is "Make any video a lesson." 

There is a free and paid version. The free version is very robust. I will not show a video unless it's been enhanced w/Edpuzzle.

#distancelearning week 3

Let's stick w/same theme of animals and switch the media from text and audio to video. 

This is where I turn to @edpuzzle. 

The Big Question from @KyleneBeers, the writing activities already mentioned still can apply.

https://t.co/YNPMxeYS3Z

#distancelearning week 3

Literacy and interrogating ideas should not be limited to a textbook or text. It should include audio as well. If you don't use @listenwiselearn, consider using the free version or better yet find the money to buy a subscription. 

It is worth it.

#distancelearning week 3

We loop back to the @listenwiselearn audio story and do writing with this, expanding the sentence and completing the fragments. 

Here is a template w/examples added. Feel free to make a copy. 

https://t.co/pPdyweTdQE

#distancelearning week 3

We use Hochman's "complete the fragment" activity next. I lift a fragment from a sentence found in the @Newsela text and we do a we do/you do where students complete fragments in breakout rooms using their own words. 

This task is harder. https://t.co/FyQeoGqJBA

#distancelearning week 3

We revisit the @Newsela story first. Students have read it twice now. 

We use Hochman's sentence expansion task where I write a short sentence based on the text & students take notes on a few question words then use them to expand the sentence. https://t.co/ytqz9x5e23

#distancelearning week 3

writing worksheets = no bueno 

I turn to @JudithCHochman & her Writing Revolution strategies.

If you haven't found this resource yet, here you go and you're welcome. :) 

https://t.co/7MnCs8FRsb

#distancelearning week 3
 
Keeping w/the same theme, we then use @listenwiselearn and this story about caring for zoo animals during a pandemic. 

We use the Somebody wanted, But, So, Then chart again to interrogate the audio & transcript. 

https://t.co/RnRezXvld9

#distancelearning week 3

We take a second pass the next day through the same article and use a new tool to help identify key information and cause and effect w/: Somebody wanted, But, So, Then. 

More magic from @KyleneBeers. 

Here's the form. https://t.co/HLuzpm9lxw
